020package org.apache.directory.server.dhcp.options.vendor;
021
022import org.apache.directory.server.dhcp.options.StringOption;
023
024/**
025 * <a href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4833">RFC 4833</a> defines new timezone options for DHCPv4. Use TCode class
026 * together with {@link PCode} instead of deprecated {@link TimeOffset}. <br>
027 * <br>
028 * POSIX provides a standard for how to express timezone information in a character string. However, for accuracy over
029 * longer periods that involve daylight- saving rule changes or other irregular changes, a more detailed mechanism is
030 * necessary. <br>
031 * <br>
032 * The <a href="http://www.twinsun.com/tz/tz-link.htm">TZ Database</a> that is used in many operating systems provides
033 * backwards consistency and accuracy for almost all real-world locations since 1970. The TZ database also attempts to
034 * provide a stable set of human readable timezone identifiers. <br>
035 * <br>
036 * TZ Name is the name of a Zone entry in the database commonly referred to as the TZ database. Specifically, in the
037 * database's textual form, the string refers to the name field of a zone line. In order for this option to be useful,
038 * the client must already have a copy of the database. This string is NOT terminated with an ASCII NULL.
039 *
040 * An example string is Europe/Zurich.
041 *
042 * @author marekgr
043 * @see <a href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4833#section-5">RFC 4833 (section 5)</a>
044 */
045public class TCode extends StringOption {
046
047    private static final short TAG = 101;
048
049    public TCode() {
050    }
051
052    /**
053     * @param tZDatabaseString
054     *            name of Zone entry in TZ Database
055     */
056    public TCode(String tZDatabaseString) {
057        setStringValue(tZDatabaseString);
058    }
059
060    /*
061     * @see org.apache.directory.server.dhcp.options.DhcpOption#getTag()
062     */
063    @Override
064    public byte getTag() {
065        return TAG;
066    }
067}
